docs.title: Grid API Reference
docs.text: The Grid class provides a 2D collection of Cell objects with convenient iteration and access patterns.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Grids organize cells into rows and columns, providing: - Simple iteration: for cell in grid - Index access: grid[row, col] - Selection methods: grid.where(), grid.border(), grid.checkerboard() - Neighbor relationships: Automatic connection between adjacent cells

docs.title: Class Definition
docs.text:
class Grid:
    """2D grid of cells."""

    def __init__(
        self,
        rows: int,
        cols: int,
        cell_width: float,
        cell_height: float,
        x_offset: float = 0,
        y_offset: float = 0
    )

Note: Grids are typically created via Scene.with_grid() or Scene.from_image().

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
grid.rows: int          # Number of rows
grid.cols: int          # Number of columns
grid.cell_width: float  # Width of each cell
grid.cell_height: float # Height of each cell
grid.width: float       # Total grid width
grid.height: float      # Total grid height

Example: 

print(f"Grid size: {grid.rows} rows × {grid.cols} cols")
print(f"Cell size: {grid.cell_width} × {grid.cell_height}")
print(f"Total dimensions: {grid.width} × {grid.height}")

docs.title: Simple Iteration
docs.text:
for cell in grid:
    # Iterates left-to-right, top-to-bottom
    cell.add_dot(radius=3, color=cell.color)

docs.title: Index Access
docs.text:
# Get specific cell
cell = grid[0, 0]        # Top-left
cell = grid[5, 10]       # Row 5, column 10

# Negative indexing works
cell = grid[-1, -1]      # Bottom-right

docs.title: Row and Column Access
docs.text:
# Get entire row
row_cells = grid.row(2)  # All cells in row 2

# Get entire column
col_cells = grid.column(5)  # All cells in column 5

Example: 

# Highlight first row
for cell in grid.row(0):
    cell.add_fill(color="yellow")

# Highlight last column
for cell in grid.column(-1):
    cell.add_border(color="red", width=2)

docs.title: where()
docs.text:
Filter cells by predicate function.

def where(self, predicate: Callable[[Cell], bool]) -> list[Cell]

Example: 

# Bright cells only
bright_cells = grid.where(lambda c: c.brightness > 0.7)

for cell in bright_cells:
    cell.add_dot(radius=5, color="gold")

docs.title: border()
docs.text:
Get cells along the grid edges.

def border(self) -> list[Cell]

Example: 

for cell in grid.border():
    cell.add_border(color="white", width=2)

docs.title: checkerboard()
docs.text:
Get cells in checkerboard pattern.

def checkerboard(self, offset: int = 0) -> list[Cell]

Parameters: - offset: 0 for one pattern, 1 for inverted

Example: 

# Create checkerboard fill
for cell in grid.checkerboard(offset=0):
    cell.add_fill(color="black")

for cell in grid.checkerboard(offset=1):
    cell.add_fill(color="white")

docs.title: corners()
docs.text:
Get the four corner cells.

def corners() -> list[Cell]

Example: 

for cell in grid.corners():
    cell.add_polygon(shapes.star(5), fill="gold")

docs.title: Full Grid Iteration
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    if cell.brightness > 0.5:
        cell.add_dot(radius=5, color=cell.color)

docs.title: Row-by-Row Processing
docs.text:
for row_idx in range(scene.grid.rows):
    for cell in scene.grid.row(row_idx):
        # Process each row separately
        pass

docs.title: Conditional Selection
docs.text:
# Only edges
for cell in scene.grid.border():
    cell.add_border(color="gold", width=2)

# Bright areas only
bright = scene.grid.where(lambda c: c.brightness > 0.7)
for cell in bright:
    cell.add_dot(radius=5, color="yellow")

docs.title: Checkerboard Patterns
docs.text:
# Black squares
for cell in grid.checkerboard(offset=0):
    cell.add_fill(color="black")

# White squares
for cell in grid.checkerboard(offset=1):
    cell.add_fill(color="white")

docs.title: Neighbor-Based Patterns
docs.text:
for cell in grid:
    dot1 = cell.add_dot(radius=3)

    # Connect to right neighbor
    if cell.right:
        dot2 = cell.right.add_dot(radius=3)
        Connection(start=dot1, end=dot2)

    # Connect to below neighbor
    if cell.below:
        dot2 = cell.below.add_dot(radius=3)
        Connection(start=dot1, end=dot2)

docs.title: Distance from Center
docs.text:
center_row = grid.rows // 2
center_col = grid.cols // 2

for cell in grid:
    dr = cell.row - center_row
    dc = cell.col - center_col
    distance = (dr*dr + dc*dc) ** 0.5

    # Use distance for sizing, coloring, etc.
    radius = 2 + (10 - distance) * 0.5
    cell.add_dot(radius=max(1, radius))

docs.title: Pathable Protocol API Reference
docs.text: The Pathable protocol defines a unified interface for positioning elements along paths.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Any entity that implements Pathable can be used with the along= parameter: - Line: Linear interpolation - Curve: Quadratic Bézier curve - Ellipse: Parametric ellipse perimeter - Custom paths: Spirals, waves, Lissajous curves

docs.title: Protocol Definition
docs.text:
class Pathable(Protocol):
    """Protocol for entities that support parametric positioning."""

    def point_at(self, t: float) -> Point:
        """
        Get point at parameter t along the path.

        Args:
            t: Parameter from 0.0 (start) to 1.0 (end)

        Returns:
            Point at that position along the path
        """
        ...

docs.title: Line
docs.text:
Linear interpolation between start and end.

line = Line(x1=0, y1=0, x2=100, y2=100)

# Get points along line
point_0 = line.point_at(0.0)    # (0, 0) - start
point_25 = line.point_at(0.25)  # (25, 25)
point_50 = line.point_at(0.5)   # (50, 50) - midpoint
point_100 = line.point_at(1.0)  # (100, 100) - end

Formula: 

P(t) = P₀ + t(P₁ - P₀)
     = (1-t)P₀ + tP₁

Where:
  P₀ = start point
  P₁ = end point
  t ∈ [0, 1]

docs.title: Curve
docs.text:
Quadratic Bézier curve.

curve = Curve(x1=0, y1=100, x2=100, y2=0, curvature=0.5)

# Get points along curve
for i in range(5):
    t = i / 4
    point = curve.point_at(t)

Formula: 

B(t) = (1-t)²P₀ + 2(1-t)tP₁ + t²P₂

Where:
  P₀ = start point
  P₁ = control point
  P₂ = end point
  t ∈ [0, 1]

docs.title: Ellipse
docs.text:
Parametric ellipse with rotation support.

ellipse = Ellipse(x=100, y=100, rx=30, ry=20, rotation=45)

# Get points around perimeter
point_0 = ellipse.point_at(0.0)    # Right (0°)
point_25 = ellipse.point_at(0.25)  # Top (90°)
point_50 = ellipse.point_at(0.5)   # Left (180°)
point_75 = ellipse.point_at(0.75)  # Bottom (270°)

# Or use angle directly
point_45 = ellipse.point_at_angle(45)  # 45° from right

Formula: 

Unrotated:
x(t) = rx × cos(2πt)
y(t) = ry × sin(2πt)

With rotation θ:
x'(t) = x(t)cos(θ) - y(t)sin(θ) + cx
y'(t) = x(t)sin(θ) + y(t)cos(θ) + cy

Where:
  rx, ry = horizontal/vertical radii
  cx, cy = center coordinates
  θ = rotation in radians
  t ∈ [0, 1] maps to [0°, 360°]

docs.title: Using with along= Parameter
docs.text:
All cell.add_* methods that create dots support the along= parameter:

# Create path
path = cell.add_curve(curvature=0.5, color="gray")

# Position dot along path
cell.add_dot(
    along=path,
    t=0.5,
    radius=4,
    color="red"
)

Example - Multiple dots along curve: 

curve = cell.add_curve(
    start="left",
    end="right",
    curvature=0.5,
    color=colors.line
)

# Position 5 dots evenly along curve
for i in range(5):
    t = i / 4  # 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0

    cell.add_dot(
        along=curve,
        t=t,
        radius=3,
        color=colors.accent
    )

docs.title: Scene API Reference
docs.text: Complete API documentation for the Scene class.

docs.title: Class: Scene
docs.text: Main container for all drawable objects.

docs.title: Constructor
docs.text: Scene(width: int, height: int, background: str | None = None)

docs.title: Factory Methods
docs.text:
@classmethod
Scene.from_image(source, grid_size=40, cell_size=10, background=None)

@classmethod
Scene.with_grid(cols, rows, cell_size, background=None)

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
• width: int - Scene width in pixels
  • height: int - Scene height in pixels
  • background: str | None - Background color
  • grid: Grid | None - Primary grid
  • entities: list[Entity] - All entities
  • connections: list[Connection] - All connections

docs.title: add()
docs.text:
def add(self, *objects: Entity | Connection | Grid) -> Entity | Connection | Grid

Add entities, connections, or grids to the scene. Can add multiple objects at once.

Parameters: - *objects: One or more Entity, Connection, or Grid objects

Returns: The last added object (for method chaining)

Example: 

from pyfreeform import Scene, Dot, Line, Connection

scene = Scene(400, 400)

# Add single entity
dot1 = Dot(100, 100, radius=10, color="red")
scene.add(dot1)

# Add multiple entities at once
dot2 = Dot(300, 300, radius=10, color="blue")
line = Line(100, 100, 300, 300, color="gray")
scene.add(dot2, line)

# Add connection
conn = Connection(start=dot1, end=dot2)
scene.add(conn)

# Method chaining
scene.add(Dot(200, 200, radius=5))

docs.title: remove()
docs.text:
def remove(self, obj: Entity | Connection | Grid) -> bool

Remove an object from the scene.

Parameters: - obj: The entity, connection, or grid to remove

Returns: True if object was found and removed, False otherwise

Example: 

dot = Dot(100, 100, radius=10)
scene.add(dot)

# Later, remove it
was_removed = scene.remove(dot)

docs.title: clear()
docs.text:
def clear(self) -> None

Remove all objects from the scene (entities, connections, and grids).

Example: 

scene.clear()  # Empty scene

docs.title: save()
docs.text:
def save(self, path: str) -> None

Save the scene as an SVG file.

Parameters: - path: File path (e.g., "artwork.svg")

Example: 

scene.save("my_art.svg")

docs.title: to_svg()
docs.text:
def to_svg(self) -> str

Generate SVG markup as a string (without saving to file).

Returns: Complete SVG document as string

Example: 

svg_content = scene.to_svg()
print(svg_content)  # View raw SVG

docs.title: Iteration Support
docs.text:
Scenes support standard Python iteration and length:

# Iterate over all entities
for entity in scene:
    print(entity)

# Count entities
num_entities = len(scene)

docs.title: Transforms API Reference
docs.text: Polygon transforms for rotation, scaling, and translation.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Polygons support geometric transformations: - rotate(): Rotate around a point - scale(): Enlarge or shrink - translate(): Move to new position

docs.title: rotate()
docs.text:
Rotate a polygon around a point.

def rotate(
    self,
    angle: float,
    origin: Point | None = None
) -> None

Parameters: - angle: Rotation angle in degrees (positive = counterclockwise) - origin: Point to rotate around (default: polygon's centroid)

Example: 

poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.hexagon(), fill="blue")

# Rotate around centroid (default)
poly.rotate(45)

# Rotate around custom point
poly.rotate(30, origin=cell.top_left)

Rotation Matrix: 

[x']   [cos(θ)  -sin(θ)] [x - ox]   [ox]
[y'] = [sin(θ)   cos(θ)] [y - oy] + [oy]

Where:
  θ = angle in radians
  (ox, oy) = origin point
  (x, y) = original vertex
  (x', y') = rotated vertex

docs.title: scale()
docs.text:
Scale a polygon by a factor.

def scale(
    self,
    factor: float,
    origin: Point | None = None
) -> None

Parameters: - factor: Scale factor (1.0 = no change, 2.0 = double size, 0.5 = half size) - origin: Point to scale from (default: polygon's centroid)

Example: 

poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.star(5), fill="gold")

# Enlarge by 50%
poly.scale(1.5)

# Shrink to 80%
poly.scale(0.8)

# Scale from custom point
poly.scale(1.2, origin=cell.center)

Scale Transformation: 

x' = ox + (x - ox) × factor
y' = oy + (y - oy) × factor

Where:
  (ox, oy) = origin point
  (x, y) = original vertex
  (x', y') = scaled vertex

docs.title: translate()
docs.text:
Move a polygon by an offset.

def translate(
    self,
    dx: float,
    dy: float
) -> None

Parameters: - dx: Horizontal offset in pixels - dy: Vertical offset in pixels

Example: 

poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.diamond(), fill="purple")

# Move right and down
poly.translate(dx=10, dy=20)

# Move left and up
poly.translate(dx=-5, dy=-10)

docs.title: Combining Transforms
docs.text:
Transforms can be chained together:

poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.hexagon(), fill="coral")

# Rotate, then scale, then translate
poly.rotate(45)
poly.scale(1.2)
poly.translate(dx=5, dy=5)

Important: Order matters! - Rotate → Scale: Rotates, then scales in rotated orientation - Scale → Rotate: Scales, then rotates the scaled shape

docs.title: Position-Based Rotation
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.hexagon(), fill=cell.color)

    # Rotation based on position
    angle = (cell.row + cell.col) * 15
    poly.rotate(angle)

docs.title: Radial Rotation
docs.text:
import math

center_row = scene.grid.rows // 2
center_col = scene.grid.cols // 2

for cell in scene.grid:
    poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.triangle(), fill=cell.color)

    # Point toward center
    dr = cell.row - center_row
    dc = cell.col - center_col
    angle = math.degrees(math.atan2(dr, dc))

    poly.rotate(angle)

docs.title: Brightness-Based Scaling
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.star(5), fill=cell.color)

    # Bright = bigger, dark = smaller
    scale_factor = 0.5 + cell.brightness * 0.5  # 0.5 to 1.0
    poly.scale(scale_factor)

docs.title: Rotation Animation
docs.text:
For animation frames:

frame = 0  # Current frame number

for cell in scene.grid:
    poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.squircle(n=4), fill=cell.color)

    # Rotation increases each frame
    angle = frame * 6  # 6° per frame
    poly.rotate(angle)

docs.title: Rotate Around Specific Points
docs.text:
# Rotate around top-left corner
poly.rotate(45, origin=cell.top_left)

# Rotate around cell center (not polygon center)
poly.rotate(45, origin=cell.center)

docs.title: Scale Before Rotation
docs.text:
For symmetrical results:

# Scale first, then rotate
poly.scale(1.5)
poly.rotate(45)

# vs

# Rotate first, then scale
poly.rotate(45)
poly.scale(1.5)  # Scales in rotated orientation

docs.title: Constrain to Cell
docs.text:
After transforms, use fit_to_cell() to ensure polygon stays within bounds:

poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.hexagon(), fill=cell.color)
poly.rotate(45)
poly.scale(1.5)

# Constrain to 90% of cell
poly.fit_to_cell(0.9)

docs.title: Shape Helpers
docs.text:
The shapes module provides pre-built polygon vertices.

from pyfreeform import shapes

All shape helpers return vertex lists in relative coordinates (0-1), perfect for use with cell.add_polygon().

Multi-pointed star.

Parameters: - points: Number of star points (5, 6, 8, etc.) - inner_radius: Ratio of inner to outer radius (0.3-0.5 works well)

Any regular polygon.

docs.title: squircle()
docs.text:
def squircle(
    size: float = 1.0,
    n: float = 4,
    center: tuple[float, float] = (0.5, 0.5)
) -> list[tuple[float, float]]

Superellipse - the iOS icon shape!

Parameters: - n: Exponent controlling shape - n=2: Circle - n=4: Classic squircle (iOS icon) - n=6+: Approaches rounded square

Mathematics: 

|x/a|ⁿ + |y/b|ⁿ = 1

Where:
  n = 2  : Perfect circle
  n = 4  : Squircle
  n → ∞  : Square

Example: 

# iOS icon shape
cell.add_polygon(shapes.squircle(n=4), fill="blue")

# Variations
for i, n in enumerate([2, 3, 4, 5, 6]):
    cell.add_polygon(shapes.squircle(n=n), fill=colors[i])

Rectangle with rounded corners.

docs.title: Point Class
docs.text:
class Point:
    """Immutable 2D point with math operations."""

    def __init__(self, x: float, y: float)

The Point class is the foundation of all positioning in PyFreeform. It's an immutable coordinate with powerful math operations.

Properties: 

point.x: float  # Horizontal coordinate
point.y: float  # Vertical coordinate

docs.title: Arithmetic Operations
docs.text:
Points support standard math operations:

from pyfreeform.core.point import Point

p1 = Point(100, 50)
p2 = Point(20, 30)

# Addition (vector addition)
p3 = p1 + p2  # Point(120, 80)

# Subtraction (vector subtraction)
p3 = p1 - p2  # Point(80, 20)

# Scalar multiplication
p3 = p1 * 2   # Point(200, 100)
p3 = 2 * p1   # Point(200, 100)

# Scalar division
p3 = p1 / 2   # Point(50, 25)

# Negation
p3 = -p1      # Point(-100, -50)

docs.title: distance_to()
docs.text:
def distance_to(self, other: Point) -> float

Calculate Euclidean distance to another point.

Example: 

p1 = Point(0, 0)
p2 = Point(100, 100)
distance = p1.distance_to(p2)  # 141.42

docs.title: lerp()
docs.text:
def lerp(self, other: Point, t: float) -> Point

Linear interpolation between two points.

Parameters: - other: Target point - t: Interpolation factor (0 = self, 1 = other)

Example: 

p1 = Point(0, 0)
p2 = Point(100, 100)

# Halfway between
mid = p1.lerp(p2, 0.5)  # Point(50, 50)

# Quarter way
quarter = p1.lerp(p2, 0.25)  # Point(25, 25)

# Extrapolate beyond
beyond = p1.lerp(p2, 1.5)  # Point(150, 150)

docs.title: midpoint()
docs.text:
def midpoint(self, other: Point) -> Point

Return the midpoint between two points (shorthand for lerp(other, 0.5)).

Example: 

p1 = Point(0, 0)
p2 = Point(100, 100)
mid = p1.midpoint(p2)  # Point(50, 50)

docs.title: normalized()
docs.text:
def normalized(self) -> Point

Return a unit vector (length = 1) pointing in the same direction.

Example: 

p = Point(3, 4)
unit = p.normalized()  # Point(0.6, 0.8)
# Length is now 1.0

docs.title: dot()
docs.text:
def dot(self, other: Point) -> float

Calculate dot product (treats points as vectors).

Example: 

p1 = Point(3, 4)
p2 = Point(1, 2)
result = p1.dot(p2)  # 11.0 (3*1 + 4*2)

docs.title: rotated()
docs.text:
def rotated(self, angle: float, origin: Point | None = None) -> Point

Rotate point around an origin.

Parameters: - angle: Rotation angle in radians (counter-clockwise) - origin: Center of rotation (default: Point(0, 0))

Example: 

import math

p = Point(100, 0)

# Rotate 90° around origin
rotated = p.rotated(math.pi / 2)  # Point(0, 100)

# Rotate around custom origin
origin = Point(50, 50)
rotated = p.rotated(math.pi / 4, origin)

docs.title: clamped()
docs.text:
def clamped(self, min_x: float, min_y: float, max_x: float, max_y: float) -> Point

Return point clamped to bounds.

Example: 

p = Point(150, -50)
clamped = p.clamped(0, 0, 100, 100)  # Point(100, 0)

docs.title: rounded()
docs.text:
def rounded(self, decimals: int = 0) -> Point

Return point with coordinates rounded.

Example: 

p = Point(3.14159, 2.71828)
rounded = p.rounded(2)  # Point(3.14, 2.72)
rounded_int = p.rounded()  # Point(3, 3)

docs.title: as_tuple()
docs.text:
def as_tuple(self) -> tuple[float, float]

Convert to plain tuple.

Example: 

p = Point(10, 20)
t = p.as_tuple()  # (10, 20)

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
from pyfreeform.core.point import Point
import math

# Create points
start = Point(0, 0)
end = Point(100, 100)

# Basic operations
direction = (end - start).normalized()  # Unit vector
halfway = start.midpoint(end)

# Rotate around center
center = Point(50, 50)
rotated = end.rotated(math.pi / 4, center)

# Distance and interpolation
dist = start.distance_to(end)
quarter = start.lerp(end, 0.25)

docs.title: map_range()
docs.text:
def map_range(
    value: float,
    in_min: float = 0,
    in_max: float = 1,
    out_min: float = 0,
    out_max: float = 1,
    clamp: bool = False
) -> float

Map a value from one range to another - essential for creative coding!

Parameters: - value: The input value to map - in_min: Input range minimum (default: 0) - in_max: Input range maximum (default: 1) - out_min: Output range minimum (default: 0) - out_max: Output range maximum (default: 1) - clamp: If True, clamp result to output range

Returns: The mapped value

Example: 

from pyfreeform import map_range

# Map brightness (0-1) to rotation (0-360)
for cell in scene.grid:
    rotation = map_range(cell.brightness, 0, 1, 0, 360)
    cell.add_text("A", rotation=rotation)

# Map brightness to radius (small when dark, large when bright)
for cell in scene.grid:
    radius = map_range(cell.brightness, 0, 1, 2, 10)
    cell.add_dot(radius=radius)

# Inverse mapping (bright = small, dark = large)
for cell in scene.grid:
    radius = map_range(cell.brightness, 0, 1, 10, 2)
    cell.add_dot(radius=radius)

# With clamping to prevent out-of-range values
size = map_range(value, 0, 100, 10, 50, clamp=True)

Note: You can also use Python math directly: 

rotation = cell.brightness * 360
radius = 2 + cell.brightness * 8

But map_range() reads more clearly and handles edge cases.

docs.title: display()
docs.text:
def display(target: Scene | str | Path) -> None

Display an SVG in your default web browser - perfect for quick previews!

Parameters: - target: Either a Scene object to render, or a path to an existing SVG file

Example: 

from pyfreeform import Scene, display

# Create and display a scene
scene = Scene.from_image("photo.jpg", grid_size=40)
for cell in scene.grid:
    cell.add_dot(color=cell.color, radius=5)

display(scene)  # Opens in browser immediately

# Or display an existing file
scene.save("artwork.svg")
display("artwork.svg")  # Opens the saved file

Use cases: - Quick preview without saving - Iterative development workflow - Opening saved SVG files

r, g, b = hex_to_rgb("#ff5733")

docs.title: Named Colors
docs.text:
PyFreeform supports all standard CSS/SVG named colors:

cell.add_dot(color="red")
cell.add_dot(color="blue")
cell.add_dot(color="green")
cell.add_dot(color="coral")
cell.add_dot(color="gold")
cell.add_dot(color="crimson")
# ... and 140+ more

Full list: aliceblue, antiquewhite, aqua, aquamarine, azure, beige, bisque, black, blanchedalmond, blue, blueviolet, brown, burlywood, cadetblue, chartreuse, chocolate, coral, cornflowerblue, cornsilk, crimson, cyan, and many more.

docs.title: Palette System
docs.text:
Built-in color schemes:

from pyfreeform import Palette

# Available palettes
colors = Palette.midnight()  # Dark blues and purples
colors = Palette.sunset()    # Warm oranges and pinks
colors = Palette.ocean()     # Cool blues and teals
colors = Palette.forest()    # Earth greens and browns
colors = Palette.pastel()    # Soft pastels
colors = Palette.neon()      # Bright neon colors
colors = Palette.monochrome()  # Grayscale
colors = Palette.paper()     # Light, paper-like theme

Palette Properties: 

colors.background: str  # Background color
colors.primary: str     # Main color
colors.secondary: str   # Secondary color
colors.accent: str      # Accent/highlight color
colors.line: str        # Line/stroke color
colors.grid: str        # Grid color

Example: 

colors = Palette.ocean()
scene.background = colors.background

for cell in scene.grid:
    if cell.brightness > 0.7:
        cell.add_dot(color=colors.accent)
    else:
        cell.add_dot(color=colors.primary)

docs.title: Color System
docs.text: PyFreeform's flexible color system supports multiple formats, making it easy to specify colors in whatever way is most convenient for your project. Whether you prefer named colors for readability, hex codes for precision, or RGB tuples for programmatic generation, PyFreeform has you covered.

docs.title: Color Formats
docs.text:
Colors in PyFreeform can be specified in three interchangeable formats:

  1. Named colors — readable strings like "red" or "coral"
  2. Hex strings — CSS-style codes like "#ff0000" or "#f00"
  3. RGB tuples — integer triplets like (255, 0, 0)

All three formats are equivalent and can be used anywhere a color is expected.

docs.title: Named Colors
docs.text:
Named colors are the most readable option, perfect for quick prototyping and when exact color values aren't critical.

cell.add_dot(color="red")
cell.add_dot(color="coral")
cell.add_dot(color="dodgerblue")

Common Named Colors

PyFreeform supports all standard CSS/SVG named colors. Here are some commonly used ones:

Reds: red, crimson, darkred, indianred, coral, salmon Blues: blue, navy, dodgerblue, steelblue, skyblue, cornflowerblue Greens: green, lime, forestgreen, seagreen, olivedrab, chartreuse Yellows/Oranges: yellow, gold, orange, darkorange, goldenrod Purples: purple, indigo, violet, orchid, magenta, plum Grays: black, dimgray, gray, darkgray, silver, lightgray, white Earth tones: brown, sienna, saddlebrown, peru, tan, burlywood

docs.title: Hex Colors
docs.text:
Hex colors provide precise control and are familiar to anyone who has worked with web design or graphic software.

cell.add_dot(color="#ff5733")
cell.add_dot(color="#f57")  # Short form

Hex Color Format

Hex colors use the format #RRGGBB where:

  • RR = red component (00-FF)
  • GG = green component (00-FF)
  • BB = blue component (00-FF)

Short form #RGB expands to #RRGGBB (e.g., #f00 → #ff0000)

Examples:

# Full form
cell.add_dot(color="#ff0000")  # Pure red
cell.add_dot(color="#00ff00")  # Pure green
cell.add_dot(color="#0000ff")  # Pure blue

# Short form
cell.add_dot(color="#f00")     # Pure red
cell.add_dot(color="#0f0")     # Pure green
cell.add_dot(color="#00f")     # Pure blue

# Mixed colors
cell.add_dot(color="#ff6b35")  # Coral orange
cell.add_dot(color="#4ecdc4")  # Turquoise

docs.title: RGB Tuples
docs.text:
RGB tuples are ideal for programmatic color generation, allowing you to compute colors mathematically.

cell.add_dot(color=(255, 87, 51))

RGB Tuple Format

RGB tuples are three-element tuples (red, green, blue) where each component is an integer from 0 to 255:

  • (255, 0, 0) = pure red
  • (0, 255, 0) = pure green
  • (0, 0, 255) = pure blue
  • (255, 255, 255) = white
  • (0, 0, 0) = black

Examples:

# Primary colors
cell.add_dot(color=(255, 0, 0))    # Red
cell.add_dot(color=(0, 255, 0))    # Green
cell.add_dot(color=(0, 0, 255))    # Blue

# Programmatic generation
for i in range(10):
    intensity = int(255 * i / 9)
    cell.add_dot(color=(intensity, 0, 255 - intensity))

# Using variables
r, g, b = 100, 150, 200
cell.add_dot(color=(r, g, b))

docs.title: Color Class
docs.text:
The Color class provides a unified interface for working with colors and converting between formats.

from pyfreeform import Color

c = Color("red")
c = Color("#ff0000")
c = Color((255, 0, 0))

# Convert to hex
hex_value = c.to_hex()  # "#ff0000"

API:

  • Color(value: str | tuple[int, int, int]) — create a Color from any format
  • color.to_hex() -> str — convert to hex string (e.g., "#ff0000")

Usage examples:

# Parse different formats
c1 = Color("crimson")
c2 = Color("#dc143c")
c3 = Color((220, 20, 60))

# All convert to the same hex
print(c1.to_hex())  # "#dc143c"
print(c2.to_hex())  # "#dc143c"
print(c3.to_hex())  # "#dc143c"

# Use in your code
def create_gradient(start_color, end_color, steps):
    start = Color(start_color)
    # ... gradient logic

docs.title: Image-Based Colors
docs.text: When working with image data, each cell provides color information derived from the underlying image.

docs.title: Cell Color Properties
docs.text:
Every cell has three color-related properties:

# Hex string of the cell's dominant color
hex_color = cell.color  # e.g., "#ff6b35"

# RGB tuple of the cell's dominant color
rgb_color = cell.rgb    # e.g., (255, 107, 53)

# Brightness value from 0.0 (black) to 1.0 (white)
brightness = cell.brightness  # e.g., 0.73

Example:

from pyfreeform import Scene

scene = Scene.from_image("photo.jpg", grid_size=20)

for cell in scene.cells:
    # Use the cell's own color
    cell.add_dot(at="center", radius=5, color=cell.color)

    # Darken bright cells
    if cell.brightness > 0.7:
        cell.add_fill(color="black", z_index=-1)

    # Access RGB components
    r, g, b = cell.rgb
    if r > 200:  # Very red cells
        cell.add_border(color="red", width=2)

Using Brightness for Effects

The brightness property is particularly useful for creating opacity-like effects or conditional rendering based on image luminosity:

for cell in scene.cells:
    # Skip dark cells
    if cell.brightness < 0.3:
        continue

    # Larger dots for brighter cells
    radius = cell.brightness * 10
    cell.add_dot(at="center", radius=radius, color="white")

docs.title: fill= vs color= Parameter Reference
docs.text:
Critical API Distinction

PyFreeform uses two different parameter names for colors depending on the entity type. Using the wrong parameter will cause errors.

Different drawing methods use different parameter names for specifying colors:

Use color= Use fill= cell.add_dot() cell.add_polygon() cell.add_line() cell.add_ellipse() cell.add_curve() Rect() cell.add_diagonal() Polygon() cell.add_text() Ellipse() cell.add_fill() cell.add_border() Dot() Line() Curve() Text() Connection style dict DotStyle LineStyle BorderStyle FillStyle

Quick rule: If it's a filled shape (polygon, ellipse, rectangle), use fill=. For everything else, use color=.

Examples:

# ✓ Correct
cell.add_dot(color="red")           # Use color=
cell.add_polygon(vertices, fill="blue")  # Use fill=
cell.add_line(start, end, color="green")  # Use color=
cell.add_ellipse(at=center, rx=10, ry=5, fill="yellow")  # Use fill=

# ✗ Wrong
cell.add_dot(fill="red")            # ERROR: use color=
cell.add_polygon(vertices, color="blue")  # ERROR: use fill=

docs.title: Creating Gradients
docs.text:
Use RGB tuples to programmatically generate color gradients:

def lerp_color(color1, color2, t):
    """Linear interpolation between two RGB colors."""
    r1, g1, b1 = color1
    r2, g2, b2 = color2
    r = int(r1 + (r2 - r1) * t)
    g = int(g1 + (g2 - g1) * t)
    b = int(b1 + (b2 - b1) * t)
    return (r, g, b)

# Create a gradient from red to blue
start = (255, 0, 0)    # Red
end = (0, 0, 255)      # Blue

for i, cell in enumerate(scene.cells[:100]):
    t = i / 99
    color = lerp_color(start, end, t)
    cell.add_fill(color=color)

docs.title: Brightness-Based Shading
docs.text:
Use the brightness property to create adaptive color schemes:

for cell in scene.cells:
    if cell.brightness > 0.8:
        # Very bright cells: dark accent
        cell.add_dot(at="center", radius=8, color="black")
    elif cell.brightness > 0.5:
        # Medium cells: colored accent
        cell.add_dot(at="center", radius=6, color=cell.color)
    else:
        # Dark cells: bright accent
        cell.add_dot(at="center", radius=4, color="white")

docs.title: Color Mixing Simulation
docs.text:
While PyFreeform doesn't have built-in alpha blending, you can simulate color mixing:

def mix_colors(color1, color2, ratio=0.5):
    """Mix two RGB colors with a given ratio."""
    r1, g1, b1 = color1
    r2, g2, b2 = color2
    r = int(r1 * ratio + r2 * (1 - ratio))
    g = int(g1 * ratio + g2 * (1 - ratio))
    b = int(b1 * ratio + b2 * (1 - ratio))
    return (r, g, b)

base = (255, 100, 50)
overlay = (50, 100, 255)
mixed = mix_colors(base, overlay, 0.7)  # 70% base, 30% overlay
cell.add_fill(color=mixed)

docs.title: Converting Between Formats
docs.text:
Convert between formats as needed:

def hex_to_rgb(hex_color):
    """Convert hex string to RGB tuple."""
    hex_color = hex_color.lstrip('#')
    if len(hex_color) == 3:
        hex_color = ''.join([c*2 for c in hex_color])
    return tuple(int(hex_color[i:i+2], 16) for i in (0, 2, 4))

def rgb_to_hex(rgb):
    """Convert RGB tuple to hex string."""
    return '#{:02x}{:02x}{:02x}'.format(*rgb)

# Usage
rgb = hex_to_rgb("#ff6b35")     # (255, 107, 53)
hex_val = rgb_to_hex((255, 107, 53))  # "#ff6b35"

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
Choosing Color Formats

  • Named colors: Quick prototyping, maximum readability
  • Hex colors: Precise control, copying from design tools
  • RGB tuples: Programmatic generation, gradients, calculations

Generative Art Color Tips

  1. Limit your palette: 3-5 colors often work better than dozens
  2. Use color theory: Complementary, analogous, or triadic color schemes
  3. Consider contrast: Ensure enough contrast for visibility
  4. Test brightness: Use cell.brightness to adapt to image data
  5. Iterate: Small color adjustments can dramatically change the feel

Common Mistakes

  • Using color= instead of fill= for polygons/ellipses
  • Using fill= instead of color= for dots/lines
  • Forgetting the # prefix for hex colors
  • RGB values outside 0-255 range (will be clamped)

docs.title: Example: Cohesive Color Palette
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Scene

# Define a consistent palette
PALETTE = {
    "primary": "#2d3436",      # Dark gray
    "secondary": "#0984e3",    # Blue
    "accent": "#fdcb6e",       # Yellow
    "highlight": "#e17055",    # Coral
    "background": "#dfe6e9",   # Light gray
}

scene = Scene.from_image("image.jpg", grid_size=30)

# Apply background
for cell in scene.cells:
    if cell.brightness < 0.3:
        cell.add_fill(color=PALETTE["primary"])
    elif cell.brightness < 0.7:
        cell.add_fill(color=PALETTE["background"])

# Add accents
for cell in scene.cells[::3]:  # Every third cell
    r, g, b = cell.rgb
    if r > g and r > b:  # Reddish cells
        cell.add_dot(at="center", radius=5, color=PALETTE["highlight"])
    else:
        cell.add_dot(at="center", radius=5, color=PALETTE["secondary"])

scene.save("output.svg")

docs.title: Entity Base Class
docs.text:
All entities inherit from Entity:

class Entity(ABC):
    def __init__(self, x, y, z_index=0):
        self._position = Point(x, y)
        self._z_index = z_index
        self._connections = WeakSet()
        self._cell = None
        self.data = {}

    # Abstract methods (must implement)
    @abstractmethod
    def anchor(self, name: str) -> Point:
        """Get anchor point by name."""
        pass

    @property
    @abstractmethod
    def anchor_names(self) -> list[str]:
        """List available anchors."""
        pass

    @abstractmethod
    def to_svg(self) -> str:
        """Render to SVG."""
        pass

    @abstractmethod
    def bounds(self) -> tuple[float, float, float, float]:
        """Get bounding box."""
        pass

docs.title: Entity Lifecycle
docs.text:
1. Construction - __init__
  2. Registration - Added to scene/cell
  3. Transformation - rotate/scale/move
  4. Rendering - to_svg() called
  5. Cleanup - Weak references prevent leaks

docs.title: Weak References
docs.text: Entities use WeakSet for connections to prevent memory leaks. When an entity is deleted, its connections are automatically cleaned up.

docs.title: Bounds Method
docs.text: The bounds() method returns a bounding box (min_x, min_y, max_x, max_y) used for hit testing, layout, and rendering optimization.

docs.title: Minimal Entity
docs.text:
from pyfreeform.core.entity import Entity
from pyfreeform.core.point import Point
from pyfreeform import Color

class Star(Entity):
    """5-pointed star entity."""

    def __init__(self, x, y, size=20, color="gold", z_index=0):
        super().__init__(x, y, z_index)
        self.size = size
        self._color = Color(color)

    @property
    def anchor_names(self) -> list[str]:
        return ["center"] + [f"point{i}" for i in range(5)]

    def anchor(self, name: str) -> Point:
        if name == "center":
            return self.position
        # Calculate point positions...
        # (implementation details)
        raise ValueError(f"Unknown anchor: {name}")

    def bounds(self) -> tuple[float, float, float, float]:
        # Return (min_x, min_y, max_x, max_y)
        return (
            self.x - self.size,
            self.y - self.size,
            self.x + self.size,
            self.y + self.size
        )

    def to_svg(self) -> str:
        # Generate SVG path for star
        return f'<path d="..." fill="{self._color.to_hex()}" />'

docs.title: Example: Wave Path
docs.text:
from pyfreeform.core.point import Point
import math

class Wave:
    def __init__(self, start, end, amplitude, frequency):
        self.start = start
        self.end = end
        self.amplitude = amplitude
        self.frequency = frequency

    def point_at(self, t: float) -> Point:
        # Linear base
        x = self.start.x + (self.end.x - self.start.x) * t
        base_y = self.start.y + (self.end.y - self.start.y) * t

        # Add wave
        wave = self.amplitude * math.sin(t * self.frequency * 2 * math.pi)
        y = base_y + wave

        return Point(x, y)

docs.title: Entity Types
docs.text:

  • Lines - Straight paths
  • Curves - Bézier curves with mathematical equations

  • Polygons - Custom shapes and helpers

Each entity has unique properties and capabilities. The mathematical entities (Curves and Ellipses) include detailed equation breakdowns.

docs.title: Dots
docs.text: Dots are the simplest entity in PyFreeform - filled circles that serve as the foundation for many artistic styles. Perfect for point-based art, pixels, particles, and dot compositions.

docs.title: What is a Dot?
docs.text:
A Dot is a filled circle entity with: - Position - Center point (x, y) - Radius - Size in pixels - Color - Fill color - Z-index - Layer ordering

Dots are the most common entity, ideal for creating dot art, halftones, scatter plots, and particle systems.

docs.title: Via Cell Method (Recommended)
docs.text:
# Simple dot at cell center
cell.add_dot(radius=5, color="coral")

# Dot at named position
cell.add_dot(at="top_left", radius=3, color="blue")

# Dot at relative coordinates
cell.add_dot(at=(0.75, 0.25), radius=4, color="red")

# Dot along a path
line = cell.add_line(start="left", end="right")
cell.add_dot(along=line, t=0.5, radius=3)

docs.title: Direct Construction
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Dot

# Create dot manually
dot = Dot(x=100, y=200, radius=10, color="coral")
scene.add(dot)

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
dot.position     # Point(x, y) - center
dot.x            # X coordinate
dot.y            # Y coordinate
dot.radius       # Radius in pixels
dot.color        # Fill color (hex string)
dot.z_index      # Layer order

docs.title: Modifying Properties
docs.text:
dot = cell.add_dot(radius=5, color="red")

# Change size
dot.radius = 10

# Change color
dot.color = "blue"
dot.color = "#ff5733"
dot.color = (255, 87, 51)

# Change layer
dot.z_index = 5

docs.title: Anchors
docs.text:
Dots have a single anchor - their center:

dot.anchor_names  # ["center"]
center = dot.anchor("center")  # Returns dot's position

docs.title: Pattern 1: Basic Dot Art
docs.text:
scene = Scene.from_image("photo.jpg", grid_size=40)

for cell in scene.grid:
    cell.add_dot(color=cell.color, radius=4)

scene.save("dot_art.svg")

docs.title: Pattern 2: Size Based on Brightness
docs.text:
Brightness-Based Sizing Creates Natural Compositions

for cell in scene.grid:
    # Larger dots in brighter areas
    size = 2 + cell.brightness * 8  # Range: 2-10
    cell.add_dot(radius=size, color=cell.color)

docs.title: Pattern 3: Conditional Rendering
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    # Only draw in bright areas
    if cell.brightness > 0.6:
        cell.add_dot(radius=6, color="yellow")

docs.title: Pattern 4: Halftone Effect
docs.text:
scene = Scene.from_image("photo.jpg", grid_size=50)
scene.background = "white"

for cell in scene.grid:
    # Invert brightness for halftone
    size = (1 - cell.brightness) * 8
    cell.add_dot(radius=size, color="black")

scene.save("halftone.svg")

docs.title: Pattern 5: Parametric Positioning
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    # Create diagonal line
    line = cell.add_diagonal(start="bottom_left", end="top_right")

    # Position dot along line based on brightness
    cell.add_dot(
        along=line,
        t=cell.brightness,  # 0.0 to 1.0
        radius=4,
        color="red"
    )

docs.title: Styling with DotStyle
docs.text:
For reusable configurations:

from pyfreeform.config import DotStyle

# Define styles
large_style = DotStyle(radius=8, color="coral")
small_style = DotStyle(radius=3, color="navy")

# Use styles
for cell in scene.grid:
    if cell.brightness > 0.5:
        cell.add_dot(style=large_style)
    else:
        cell.add_dot(style=small_style)

# Create variations
blue_large = large_style.with_color("blue")
huge_coral = large_style.with_radius(15)

docs.title: Movement and Transforms
docs.text:
Dots support all standard entity operations:

dot = cell.add_dot(radius=5, color="red")

# Move
dot.move_to(100, 200)
dot.move_by(dx=10, dy=-5)

# Scale (changes radius)
dot.scale(2.0)  # Double the radius
dot.scale(0.5)  # Half the radius

# Rotate (no visual effect for circles, but updates internal rotation)
dot.rotate(45)

docs.title: Layering
docs.text:
Control render order with z-index:

# Background dots
cell.add_dot(radius=8, color="lightgray", z_index=0)

# Middle layer
cell.add_dot(radius=5, color="gray", z_index=1)

# Foreground dots
cell.add_dot(radius=3, color="black", z_index=2)

Higher z-index renders on top.

docs.title: Example 1: Grid with Variable Sizing
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Scene, Palette

scene = Scene.with_grid(cols=20, rows=20, cell_size=15)
colors = Palette.ocean()
scene.background = colors.background

for cell in scene.grid:
    # Distance from center
    dx = cell.col - 10
    dy = cell.row - 10
    distance = (dx*dx + dy*dy) ** 0.5

    # Size decreases with distance
    max_distance = (10*10 + 10*10) ** 0.5
    size = 2 + (1 - distance / max_distance) * 8

    cell.add_dot(radius=size, color=colors.primary)

scene.save("radial_dots.svg")

docs.title: Example 2: Multi-Color Composition
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Scene, Palette

scene = Scene.from_image("photo.jpg", grid_size=40)
colors = Palette.midnight()
scene.background = colors.background

for cell in scene.grid:
    if cell.brightness > 0.7:
        cell.add_dot(radius=6, color=colors.primary)
    elif cell.brightness > 0.4:
        cell.add_dot(radius=4, color=colors.secondary)
    elif cell.brightness > 0.2:
        cell.add_dot(radius=2, color=colors.accent)

scene.save("threshold_dots.svg")

docs.title: Tips and Best Practices
docs.text:
Start with Dots

Dots are the easiest entity to work with - great for prototyping:

# Quick prototype
for cell in scene.grid:
    cell.add_dot(color=cell.color)

docs.title: Use Brightness for Size
docs.text:
Creates natural-looking compositions:

size = min_size + cell.brightness * (max_size - min_size)

docs.title: Layer Large Before Small
docs.text:
For depth:

cell.add_dot(radius=10, color="lightgray", z_index=0)  # Background
cell.add_dot(radius=5, color="gray", z_index=1)        # Middle
cell.add_dot(radius=2, color="black", z_index=2)       # Foreground

docs.title: Consider Overlap
docs.text:
Overlapping Can Be Artistic

Large dots may overlap neighbors - this can create interesting effects:

# Intentional overlap for organic feel
cell.add_dot(radius=cell.width * 0.7, color=cell.color)

docs.title: Lines
docs.text: Lines create straight paths between two points. Simple, versatile, and essential for structure, grids, and connections.

docs.title: What is a Line?
docs.text:
A Line is a straight path entity with: - Start point - Beginning (x1, y1) - End point - Ending (x2, y2) - Width - Stroke width - Color - Stroke color - Cap - Endpoint style

Lines support parametric positioning, making them useful as paths for other entities.

docs.title: Via Cell Method
docs.text:
# Named positions
cell.add_line(start="top_left", end="bottom_right")

# Relative coordinates (0-1)
cell.add_line(start=(0.2, 0.2), end=(0.8, 0.8))

# Diagonal shortcuts
cell.add_diagonal(start="top_left", end="bottom_right")  # NW to SE
cell.add_diagonal(start="bottom_left", end="top_right")  # SW to NE

docs.title: Direct Construction
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Line

# From coordinates
line = Line(x1=0, y1=0, x2=100, y2=100, width=2, color="black")

# From points
from pyfreeform.core.point import Point
line = Line.from_points(
    start=Point(0, 0),
    end=Point(100, 100),
    width=2
)

scene.add(line)

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
line.start        # Start point
line.end          # End point
line.width        # Stroke width
line.color        # Stroke color
line.z_index      # Layer order

docs.title: Parametric Positioning
docs.text:
Position elements along the line:

line = cell.add_line(start="left", end="right")

# Linear interpolation from start (t=0) to end (t=1)
point_at_start = line.point_at(0)
point_at_middle = line.point_at(0.5)
point_at_end = line.point_at(1.0)

# Position dots along line
cell.add_dot(along=line, t=0.25, radius=3)
cell.add_dot(along=line, t=0.5, radius=3)
cell.add_dot(along=line, t=0.75, radius=3)

Formula: 

P(t) = start + (end - start) × t
     = start × (1-t) + end × t

docs.title: Anchors
docs.text:
line.anchor_names  # ["start", "center", "end"]

line.anchor("start")   # Start point
line.anchor("center")  # Midpoint (t=0.5)
line.anchor("end")     # End point

docs.title: Curves
docs.text: Curves bring organic, flowing shapes to your artwork using quadratic Bézier mathematics. Perfect for smooth paths, flowing compositions, and natural-looking connections.

docs.title: What is a Curve?
docs.text:
A Curve is a smooth, parametric path defined by: - Start point - Beginning of the curve - End point - End of the curve - Control point - Determines the curve's bow (calculated from curvature) - Curvature - How much the curve bows away from a straight line

Curves use quadratic Bézier mathematics to create smooth, controllable paths.

docs.title: Quadratic Bézier Formula
docs.text:
PyFreeform curves use the quadratic Bézier equation:

B(t) = (1-t)²P₀ + 2(1-t)tP₁ + t²P₂

Where:
  t ∈ [0,1]  : Parameter along the curve
  P₀         : Start point
  P₁         : Control point
  P₂         : End point

Expanded form:

x(t) = (1-t)²·x₀ + 2(1-t)t·x₁ + t²·x₂
y(t) = (1-t)²·y₀ + 2(1-t)t·y₁ + t²·y₂

How it works: - At t=0: B(0) = P₀ (start point) - At t=0.5: B(0.5) = midpoint influenced by control point - At t=1: B(1) = P₂ (end point)

The control point P₁ "pulls" the curve toward it, creating the smooth bow.

docs.title: Control Point Calculation
docs.text:
The control point is calculated from the curvature parameter:

1. midpoint = (P₀ + P₂) / 2

2. direction = P₂ - P₀
   length = ||direction||

3. perpendicular = rotate(direction, 90°)
   normalized_perp = perpendicular / length

4. offset = curvature × length × 0.5

5. control = midpoint + normalized_perp × offset

In code (from curve.py:134-157):

def _calculate_control(self) -> Point:
    # Midpoint of start and end
    mid = self.start.midpoint(self.end)

    if self.curvature == 0:
        return mid  # Straight line

    # Vector from start to end
    dx = self.end.x - self.start.x
    dy = self.end.y - self.start.y
    length = sqrt(dx**2 + dy**2)

    # Perpendicular vector (rotate 90° counterclockwise)
    perp_x = -dy / length
    perp_y = dx / length

    # Offset by curvature * half the length
    offset = self.curvature * length * 0.5

    return Point(
        mid.x + perp_x * offset,
        mid.y + perp_y * offset
    )

docs.title: Curvature Parameter
docs.text:
Understanding Curvature

The curvature parameter controls the bow:

curvature = 0     : Straight line (no curve)
curvature > 0     : Bows to the left (when facing end point)
curvature < 0     : Bows to the right
curvature = ±1    : Standard bow (common range: -1 to 1)

Visual examples:

curvature = 0       curvature = 0.5      curvature = -0.5
(straight)          (left bow)           (right bow)

P₀ ────── P₂       P₀           P₂      P₀           P₂
                        ╲       ╱              ╲   ╱
                         ╲     ╱                ╲ ╱
                          ╲   ╱                  ╳
                           ╲ ╱                  ╱ ╲
                            P₁                 ╱   ╲
                                              P₁

docs.title: Via Cell Method (Recommended)
docs.text:
# Basic curve
cell.add_curve(
    start="bottom_left",
    end="top_right",
    curvature=0.5,
    color="blue",
    width=2
)

# Curve from relative coordinates
cell.add_curve(
    start=(0.2, 0.8),
    end=(0.8, 0.2),
    curvature=0.5
)

docs.title: Direct Construction
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Curve

# From coordinates
curve = Curve(x1=0, y1=100, x2=100, y2=0, curvature=0.5)

# From points
from pyfreeform.core.point import Point
curve = Curve.from_points(
    start=Point(0, 100),
    end=Point(100, 0),
    curvature=0.5
)

scene.add(curve)

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
curve.start        # Start point (Point object)
curve.end          # End point (Point object)
curve.control      # Control point (calculated)
curve.curvature    # Curvature amount
curve.color        # Stroke color
curve.width        # Stroke width
curve.z_index      # Layer order

docs.title: Modifying Properties
docs.text:
curve = cell.add_curve(curvature=0.5, color="blue")

# Change curvature
curve.curvature = -0.5  # Flip the bow

# Change endpoints
curve.end = Point(200, 300)

# Change styling
curve.color = "red"
curve.width = 3

docs.title: Parametric Positioning
docs.text:
The Killer Feature

Position elements along the curve:

# Create curve
curve = cell.add_curve(
    start="left",
    end="right",
    curvature=0.5
)

# Get point at parameter t (0 to 1)
point = curve.point_at(0.5)  # Midpoint of curve

# Position dots along curve
for i in range(5):
    t = i / 4  # 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0
    cell.add_dot(
        along=curve,
        t=t,
        radius=3,
        color="red"
    )

Mathematical implementation:

def point_at(self, t: float) -> Point:
    """Get point on curve at parameter t."""
    p0, p1, p2 = self.start, self.control, self.end

    mt = 1 - t
    mt2 = mt * mt    # (1-t)²
    t2 = t * t        # t²

    # Quadratic Bézier formula
    x = mt2 * p0.x + 2 * mt * t * p1.x + t2 * p2.x
    y = mt2 * p0.y + 2 * mt * t * p1.y + t2 * p2.y

    return Point(x, y)

docs.title: Anchors
docs.text:
Curves provide these anchor points:

curve.anchor_names  # ["start", "center", "end", "control"]

curve.anchor("start")    # Start point
curve.anchor("center")   # Midpoint (t=0.5)
curve.anchor("end")      # End point
curve.anchor("control")  # Control point (off the curve)

docs.title: Pattern 1: Brightness-Driven Positioning
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    curve = cell.add_curve(
        start="bottom_left",
        end="top_right",
        curvature=0.5,
        color="gray"
    )

    # Dot slides along curve based on brightness
    cell.add_dot(
        along=curve,
        t=cell.brightness,  # 0.0 to 1.0
        radius=4,
        color="red"
    )

docs.title: Pattern 2: Variable Curvature
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    # Curvature varies across the grid
    curvature = (cell.col / scene.grid.cols - 0.5) * 2  # -1 to 1

    curve = cell.add_curve(
        start="left",
        end="right",
        curvature=curvature,
        color=cell.color
    )

Creates a flowing wave pattern across the grid.

docs.title: Pattern 3: Multiple Dots Along Curve
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    if cell.brightness > 0.4:
        curve = cell.add_curve(curvature=0.5, color="lightgray")

        # Position multiple dots
        for i in range(5):
            t = i / 4
            cell.add_dot(
                along=curve,
                t=t,
                radius=2,
                color="coral"
            )

docs.title: Pattern 4: Connecting Cells
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    if cell.right:  # Has neighbor to the right
        # Curve from this cell to neighbor
        curve = Curve.from_points(
            start=cell.center,
            end=cell.right.center,
            curvature=0.3,
            color="blue",
            width=1
        )
        scene.add(curve)

docs.title: Visualizing the Bézier Formula
docs.text:
The quadratic Bézier is a weighted average of three points:

At t=0.0:  All weight on P₀ (start)
At t=0.25: Mostly P₀, some P₁, little P₂
At t=0.5:  Balanced blend (closer to P₁)
At t=0.75: Mostly P₂, some P₁, little P₀
At t=1.0:  All weight on P₂ (end)

Weight distribution:

# Weights at t=0.5
(1-0.5)² = 0.25       # Weight on P₀ (start)
2(1-0.5)(0.5) = 0.50  # Weight on P₁ (control)
(0.5)² = 0.25         # Weight on P₂ (end)
# Total = 1.0

docs.title: Derivatives (Advanced)
docs.text:
The first derivative gives the tangent (velocity) along the curve:

B'(t) = 2(1-t)(P₁ - P₀) + 2t(P₂ - P₁)

Useful for: - Computing normals (perpendicular directions) - Arc length approximation - Velocity-based animations

docs.title: Arc Length (Advanced)
docs.text:
The exact arc length requires numerical integration. Approximation:

def approximate_length(curve, segments=10):
    length = 0
    prev = curve.point_at(0)

    for i in range(1, segments + 1):
        t = i / segments
        curr = curve.point_at(t)
        length += prev.distance_to(curr)
        prev = curr

    return length

docs.title: Styling Curves
docs.text:
from pyfreeform.config import LineStyle

# Create reusable style
style = LineStyle(
    width=2,
    color="navy",
    cap="round"  # "round", "square", or "butt"

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Scene, Palette

scene = Scene.from_image("photo.jpg", grid_size=30)
colors = Palette.ocean()
scene.background = colors.background

for cell in scene.grid:
    # Only in medium brightness areas
    if 0.3 < cell.brightness < 0.7:
        # Curvature driven by brightness
        curvature = (cell.brightness - 0.5) * 2  # -0.4 to 0.4

        # Create curve
        curve = cell.add_curve(
            start="bottom_left",
            end="top_right",
            curvature=curvature,
            color=colors.line,
            width=1,
            z_index=1
        )

        # Add dots along curve
        for i in range(3):
            t = i / 2  # 0, 0.5, 1.0
            cell.add_dot(
                along=curve,
                t=t,
                radius=2,
                color=colors.accent,
                z_index=2
            )

scene.save("flowing_curves.svg")

docs.title: Tips and Best Practices
docs.text:
Keep Curvature in Range

Keep curvature in the -1 to 1 range for natural-looking curves:

# Good - natural curves
curvature = 0.5

# Extreme - can create loops or sharp bends
curvature = 3.0

docs.title: Use with Image Data
docs.text:
Brightness makes great parametric drivers:

curve = cell.add_curve(curvature=0.5)
cell.add_dot(along=curve, t=cell.brightness)  # Smooth distribution

docs.title: Visualize Control Points
docs.text:
For debugging, show the control point:

curve = cell.add_curve(curvature=0.5, color="blue")
control = curve.anchor("control")
cell.add_dot(at=control, radius=2, color="red", z_index=10)

Mix curves and lines for variety:

    cell.add_curve(curvature=0.5)
else:
    cell.add_line(start="left", end="right")

docs.title: Ellipses
docs.text: Ellipses bring rotatable ovals and circles to your artwork with powerful parametric positioning. Perfect for radial compositions, orbits, and dynamic rotations.

docs.title: What is an Ellipse?
docs.text:
An Ellipse is an oval or circle entity defined by: - Center - Position (x, y) - rx - Horizontal radius (half-width) - ry - Vertical radius (half-height) - Rotation - Angle in degrees - Fill - Interior color - Stroke - Border color (optional)

Ellipses support parametric positioning around their perimeter, making them powerful for creating radial patterns and animations.

docs.title: Parametric Ellipse Equations
docs.text:
An ellipse is defined parametrically by these equations:

Unrotated ellipse:

x(t) = rx × cos(2πt)
y(t) = ry × sin(2πt)

Where:
  t ∈ [0,1]  : Parameter around the ellipse
  rx         : Horizontal radius
  ry         : Vertical radius
  t=0        : Right side (0°)
  t=0.25     : Top (90°)
  t=0.5      : Left side (180°)
  t=0.75     : Bottom (270°)
  t=1        : Back to right (360°)

With rotation θ (in radians):

x'(t) = x(t)·cos(θ) - y(t)·sin(θ) + cx
y'(t) = x(t)·sin(θ) + y(t)·cos(θ) + cy

Where:
  θ  : Rotation angle
  cx : Center x coordinate
  cy : Center y coordinate

Full formula with rotation:

x'(t) = cx + rx·cos(2πt)·cos(θ) - ry·sin(2πt)·sin(θ)
y'(t) = cy + rx·cos(2πt)·sin(θ) + ry·sin(2πt)·cos(θ)

docs.title: Alternative: Angle-Based Positioning
docs.text:
You can also specify positions by angle in degrees:

angle_rad = angle_deg × π/180

x = rx × cos(angle_rad)
y = ry × sin(angle_rad)

# Then apply rotation transformation

docs.title: In PyFreeform Code
docs.text:
From ellipse.py:

def point_at(self, t: float) -> Point:
    """Get point at parameter t (0 to 1) around ellipse."""
    # Convert t to angle (0 to 2π)
    angle = t * 2 * math.pi

    # Unrotated ellipse point
    x = self.rx * math.cos(angle)
    y = self.ry * math.sin(angle)

    # Apply rotation if needed
    if self.rotation != 0:
        rot_rad = math.radians(self.rotation)
        cos_r = math.cos(rot_rad)
        sin_r = math.sin(rot_rad)

        # Rotation matrix
        x_rot = x * cos_r - y * sin_r
        y_rot = x * sin_r + y * cos_r

        x, y = x_rot, y_rot

    # Translate to center
    return Point(self.position.x + x, self.position.y + y)


def point_at_angle(self, degrees: float) -> Point:
    """Get point at specific angle in degrees."""
    # Convert angle to radians
    angle_rad = math.radians(degrees)

    # Same as above but using direct angle
    x = self.rx * math.cos(angle_rad)
    y = self.ry * math.sin(angle_rad)

    # Apply rotation...
    # (same rotation logic)

docs.title: Via Cell Method (Recommended)
docs.text:
# Circle (rx == ry)
cell.add_ellipse(rx=10, ry=10, fill="coral")

# Oval (rx != ry)
cell.add_ellipse(rx=15, ry=8, fill="blue")

# Rotated ellipse
cell.add_ellipse(
    rx=15,
    ry=8,
    rotation=45,  # degrees
    fill="purple"
)

# With stroke
cell.add_ellipse(
    rx=12,
    ry=12,
    fill="lightblue",
    stroke="navy",
    stroke_width=2
)

docs.title: Direct Construction
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Ellipse

# At specific position
ellipse = Ellipse(x=100, y=200, rx=20, ry=15, rotation=30)

# At center point
from pyfreeform.core.point import Point
ellipse = Ellipse.at_center(
    center=Point(100, 200),
    rx=20,
    ry=15,
    rotation=30
)

scene.add(ellipse)

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
ellipse.position    # Center point (Point object)
ellipse.x           # Center x coordinate
ellipse.y           # Center y coordinate
ellipse.rx          # Horizontal radius
ellipse.ry          # Vertical radius
ellipse.rotation    # Rotation in degrees
ellipse.fill        # Fill color
ellipse.stroke      # Stroke color (or None)
ellipse.stroke_width  # Stroke width
ellipse.z_index     # Layer order

docs.title: Modifying Properties
docs.text:
ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(rx=15, ry=10)

# Change size
ellipse.rx = 20
ellipse.ry = 12

# Rotate
ellipse.rotation = 45

# Change colors

ellipse.stroke = "darkred"
ellipse.stroke_width = 2

docs.title: Parametric Positioning
docs.text: Position elements around the ellipse perimeter:

docs.title: Using Parameter t (0 to 1)
docs.text:
ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(rx=15, ry=10)

# Position dots around ellipse
for i in range(8):
    t = i / 8  # 0, 0.125, 0.25, ..., 0.875
    cell.add_dot(
        along=ellipse,
        t=t,
        radius=2,
        color="red"
    )

docs.title: Using Direct Angles
docs.text:
ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(rx=15, ry=10, rotation=30)

# Position at specific angles
point_0 = ellipse.point_at_angle(0)    # Right
point_90 = ellipse.point_at_angle(90)  # Top
point_180 = ellipse.point_at_angle(180)  # Left
point_270 = ellipse.point_at_angle(270)  # Bottom

docs.title: Relationship Between t and Angle
docs.text:
t = 0    → angle = 0°   (right)
t = 0.25 → angle = 90°  (top)
t = 0.5  → angle = 180° (left)
t = 0.75 → angle = 270° (bottom)
t = 1.0  → angle = 360° (back to right)

angle_degrees = t × 360

docs.title: Anchors
docs.text:
Ellipses provide cardinal direction anchors:

ellipse.anchor_names  # ["center", "right", "top", "left", "bottom"]

ellipse.anchor("center")  # Center point
ellipse.anchor("right")   # Rightmost point (0°)
ellipse.anchor("top")     # Topmost point (90°)
ellipse.anchor("left")    # Leftmost point (180°)
ellipse.anchor("bottom")  # Bottommost point (270°)

These automatically account for rotation!

docs.title: Pattern 1: Brightness-Sized Ellipses
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    # Size based on brightness
    scale = 0.3 + cell.brightness * 0.7  # 30% to 100%

    ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(
        rx=cell.width * 0.4,
        ry=cell.height * 0.4,
        fill=cell.color
    )

    # Fit to cell with dynamic size
    ellipse.fit_to_cell(scale)

docs.title: Pattern 2: Rotating Ellipses
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    # Rotation based on position
    rotation = (cell.row + cell.col) * 15  # degrees

    ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(
        rx=12,
        ry=8,
        rotation=rotation,
        fill=cell.color
    )

Creates a spiral rotation pattern across the grid.

docs.title: Pattern 3: Orbiting Dots
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    if cell.brightness > 0.5:
        # Create ellipse path
        ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(
            rx=10,
            ry=8,
            rotation=45,
            fill=None,  # Invisible path
            stroke="lightgray",
            stroke_width=0.5
        )

        # Position dot along ellipse based on brightness
        cell.add_dot(
            along=ellipse,
            t=cell.brightness,
            radius=3,
            color="red"
        )

docs.title: Pattern 4: Radial Composition
docs.text:
center_row = scene.grid.rows // 2
center_col = scene.grid.cols // 2

for cell in scene.grid:
    # Distance from center
    dr = cell.row - center_row
    dc = cell.col - center_col
    distance = (dr*dr + dc*dc) ** 0.5

    # Angle from center
    angle = math.atan2(dr, dc) * 180 / math.pi

    # Create rotated ellipse
    ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(
        rx=8,
        ry=5,
        rotation=angle,  # Points toward center
        fill=cell.color
    )

docs.title: Eccentricity
docs.text:
The eccentricity measures how "stretched" an ellipse is:

e = sqrt(1 - (ry/rx)²)   when rx > ry

e = 0     : Perfect circle (rx == ry)
0 < e < 1 : Ellipse
e = 1     : Parabola (theoretical limit)

In PyFreeform:

def eccentricity(ellipse):
    if ellipse.rx == ellipse.ry:
        return 0  # Circle

    a = max(ellipse.rx, ellipse.ry)  # Semi-major axis
    b = min(ellipse.rx, ellipse.ry)  # Semi-minor axis

    return math.sqrt(1 - (b/a)**2)

docs.title: Perimeter Approximation
docs.text:
The exact perimeter of an ellipse requires an elliptic integral. Ramanujan's approximation:

P ≈ π[3(a+b) - sqrt((3a+b)(a+3b))]

Where:
  a = rx (semi-major axis)
  b = ry (semi-minor axis)

Implementation:

def approximate_perimeter(ellipse):
    a, b = ellipse.rx, ellipse.ry
    h = ((a - b)**2) / ((a + b)**2)

    # Ramanujan's first approximation
    return math.pi * (a + b) * (1 + 3*h / (10 + math.sqrt(4 - 3*h)))

docs.title: Area
docs.text:
The exact area is simple:

A = π × rx × ry

For circles: A = πr² (special case where rx = ry = r)

docs.title: Rotation Matrix
docs.text:
The 2D rotation transformation:

[x']   [cos(θ)  -sin(θ)] [x]
[y'] = [sin(θ)   cos(θ)] [y]

Expanded:
x' = x·cos(θ) - y·sin(θ)
y' = x·sin(θ) + y·cos(θ)

This is how PyFreeform rotates ellipse points.

docs.title: Auto-Fitting to Cells
docs.text:
Ellipses support automatic constraining:

for cell in scene.grid:
    # Create large ellipse
    ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(
        rx=100,  # Way too large
        ry=60,
        rotation=45,
        fill=cell.color
    )

    # Auto-fit to 85% of cell
    # Handles rotation automatically!
    ellipse.fit_to_cell(0.85)

The fit_to_cell() method: 1. Calculates the rotated bounding box 2. Finds the scale factor to fit within the cell 3. Scales both rx and ry proportionally 4. Optionally recenters in the cell

docs.title: Circles vs. Ellipses
docs.text:
A circle is just an ellipse where rx == ry:

# These are equivalent
circle = cell.add_ellipse(rx=10, ry=10)  # rx == ry
circle = cell.add_ellipse(rx=10, ry=10, rotation=0)  # Rotation doesn't matter

Tip: For circles, rotation has no visual effect.

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Scene, Palette
import math

scene = Scene.from_image("photo.jpg", grid_size=30)
colors = Palette.ocean()
scene.background = colors.background

center_row = scene.grid.rows // 2
center_col = scene.grid.cols // 2

for cell in scene.grid:
    # Calculate position relative to center
    dr = cell.row - center_row
    dc = cell.col - center_col
    distance = (dr*dr + dc*dc) ** 0.5
    angle = math.degrees(math.atan2(dr, dc))

    # Size based on brightness
    scale = 0.3 + cell.brightness * 0.7

    # Create rotated ellipse pointing toward/away from center
    ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(
        rx=15,
        ry=8,
        rotation=angle,
        fill=cell.color,
        z_index=1
    )
    ellipse.fit_to_cell(scale)

    # Add dot on ellipse perimeter
    cell.add_dot(
        along=ellipse,
        t=cell.brightness,
        radius=2,
        color=colors.accent,
        z_index=2
    )

scene.save("radial_ellipses.svg")

docs.title: Use fit_to_cell() for Rotated Ellipses
docs.text:
It handles the rotated bounding box automatically:

ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(rx=20, ry=10, rotation=45)
ellipse.fit_to_cell(0.85)  # Perfect fit despite rotation

docs.title: Brightness for Dynamic Rotation
docs.text:
rotation = cell.brightness * 360  # 0° to 360°
ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(rx=15, ry=8, rotation=rotation)

docs.title: Invisible Paths
docs.text:
Use ellipses as paths without drawing them:

path = cell.add_ellipse(
    rx=12,
    ry=12,
    fill=None,
    stroke=None
)
cell.add_dot(along=path, t=0.25)  # Path guides position

docs.title: Combine with Image Data
docs.text:
Let brightness drive position:

ellipse = cell.add_ellipse(rx=15, ry=10)
cell.add_dot(along=ellipse, t=cell.brightness)  # Smooth distribution

docs.title: Polygons
docs.text: Polygons bring geometric shapes to your artwork. Create custom forms or use built-in helpers for triangles, hexagons, stars, squircles, and more.

docs.title: What is a Polygon?
docs.text:
A Polygon is a closed shape defined by vertices with: - Vertices - List of points forming the shape - Fill - Interior color - Stroke - Border color (optional) - Centroid - Center point (calculated automatically)

Polygons can have any number of vertices (minimum 3) and support both fill and stroke styling.

docs.title: Via Cell Method with Shape Helpers
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import shapes

# Built-in shapes (relative coordinates 0-1)
cell.add_polygon(shapes.triangle(), fill="red")
cell.add_polygon(shapes.square(), fill="blue")
cell.add_polygon(shapes.hexagon(), fill="purple")
cell.add_polygon(shapes.star(points=5), fill="gold")
cell.add_polygon(shapes.diamond(), fill="coral")

# Advanced shapes
cell.add_polygon(shapes.squircle(), fill="blue")  # iOS icon shape!
cell.add_polygon(shapes.rounded_rect(corner_radius=0.2), fill="green")

docs.title: Custom Vertices
docs.text:
# Relative coordinates within cell (0-1)
triangle = [(0.5, 0), (1, 1), (0, 1)]  # Top center, bottom right, bottom left
cell.add_polygon(triangle, fill="orange")

# Or absolute coordinates
vertices = [(10, 10), (50, 10), (30, 50)]
polygon = Polygon(vertices, fill="blue")
scene.add(polygon)

docs.title: Built-In Shape Helpers
docs.text: All helpers return vertex lists in relative coordinates (0-1):

docs.title: triangle(size=1.0, center=(0.5, 0.5))
docs.text: Equilateral triangle pointing up.

docs.title: square(size=1.0, center=(0.5, 0.5))
docs.text: Perfect square (45° rotated from rectangle).

docs.title: diamond(size=1.0, center=(0.5, 0.5))
docs.text: Diamond shape (square rotated 45°).

docs.title: hexagon(size=1.0, center=(0.5, 0.5))
docs.text: Regular hexagon with flat top.

docs.title: star(points=5, size=1.0, inner_radius=0.4, center=(0.5, 0.5))
docs.text: Multi-pointed star. - points: Number of star points (5, 6, 8, etc.) - inner_radius: Ratio of inner to outer radius (0.3-0.5 works well)

docs.title: regular_polygon(n_sides, size=1.0, center=(0.5, 0.5))
docs.text: Any regular polygon. - n_sides: 5 = pentagon, 6 = hexagon, 7 = heptagon, 8 = octagon, etc.

docs.title: squircle(size=1.0, n=4, center=(0.5, 0.5))
docs.text: Superellipse - the iOS icon shape! - n=2: Circle - n=4: Classic squircle (iOS icon) - n=6+: Approaches rounded square

docs.title: rounded_rect(size=1.0, corner_radius=0.1, center=(0.5, 0.5))
docs.text: Rectangle with rounded corners. - corner_radius: 0=sharp, 0.3=very round

docs.title: The Mathematics of Squircles
docs.text:
Squircles use the superellipse equation:

|x/a|ⁿ + |y/b|ⁿ = 1

Where:
  a, b : Semi-axes (typically equal for squircles)
  n    : Exponent controlling shape

  n = 2  : Perfect circle (Pythagorean)
  n = 4  : Squircle (iOS-style)
  n → ∞  : Square with sharp corners

Parametric form:

def sgn_pow(val, exp):
    """Signed power function."""
    return sign(val) × |val|^exp

For angle θ from 0 to 2π:
    x = sgn_pow(cos(θ), 2/n) × radius
    y = sgn_pow(sin(θ), 2/n) × radius

Why it works: - Low n (like 2): Creates smooth circular curves - High n (like 4): Creates smooth rounded squares - The signed power preserves quadrant information

From polygon.py implementation.

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
polygon.vertices     # List of Point objects
polygon.position     # Centroid (center of mass)
polygon.fill         # Fill color
polygon.stroke       # Stroke color
polygon.stroke_width # Border width
polygon.z_index      # Layer order

docs.title: Centroid Calculation
docs.text:
The position is automatically calculated as the centroid:

centroid_x = Σ(vertex_x) / vertex_count
centroid_y = Σ(vertex_y) / vertex_count

docs.title: Anchors
docs.text:
polygon.anchor_names  # ["center", "v0", "v1", "v2", ...]

polygon.anchor("center")  # Centroid
polygon.anchor("v0")      # First vertex
polygon.anchor("v1")      # Second vertex
# etc.

docs.title: Pattern 1: Shape Gallery
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import shapes, Palette

scene = Scene.with_grid(cols=8, rows=6, cell_size=20)
colors = Palette.pastel()

shape_grid = [
    shapes.triangle(),
    shapes.square(),
    shapes.diamond(),
    shapes.hexagon(),
    shapes.star(5),
    shapes.star(6),
    shapes.star(8),
    shapes.regular_polygon(7)
]

for i, cell in enumerate(scene.grid):
    shape_idx = i % len(shape_grid)
    cell.add_polygon(shape_grid[shape_idx], fill=colors.primary)

docs.title: Pattern 2: Rotating Shapes
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    # Rotation based on position
    rotation = (cell.row + cell.col) * 15

    poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.hexagon(), fill=cell.color)
    poly.rotate(rotation)

docs.title: Pattern 3: Conditional Shapes
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    if cell.brightness > 0.7:
        cell.add_polygon(shapes.hexagon(), fill="gold")
    elif cell.brightness > 0.4:
        cell.add_polygon(shapes.diamond(), fill="silver")
    else:
        cell.add_polygon(shapes.triangle(), fill="bronze")

docs.title: Pattern 4: Custom Star Burst
docs.text:
# Create custom star shape
def custom_star(points=8):
    vertices = []
    for i in range(points * 2):
        angle = -90 + i * 180 / points  # Start from top
        r = 0.8 if i % 2 == 0 else 0.3  # Alternate radii
        x = 0.5 + r * math.cos(math.radians(angle))
        y = 0.5 + r * math.sin(math.radians(angle))
        vertices.append((x, y))
    return vertices

cell.add_polygon(custom_star(8), fill="orange")

docs.title: Transforms
docs.text:
Polygons support rotation and scaling:

poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.hexagon(), fill="purple")

# Rotate around centroid
poly.rotate(45)

# Rotate around custom point
poly.rotate(30, origin=cell.top_left)

# Scale from centroid
poly.scale(1.5)

# Scale from custom point
poly.scale(0.8, origin=cell.center)

docs.title: Styling
docs.text:
# Fill only
cell.add_polygon(shapes.star(5), fill="gold")

# Stroke only
cell.add_polygon(shapes.hexagon(), fill=None, stroke="navy", stroke_width=2)

# Both fill and stroke
cell.add_polygon(
    shapes.diamond(),
    fill="lightblue",
    stroke="darkblue",
    stroke_width=1
)

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Scene, Palette, shapes

scene = Scene.with_grid(cols=15, rows=15, cell_size=20)
colors = Palette.ocean()
scene.background = colors.background

for cell in scene.grid:
    # Distance from center
    dx = cell.col - 7.5
    dy = cell.row - 7.5
    distance = (dx*dx + dy*dy) ** 0.5

    # Choose shape by distance
    if distance < 3:
        shape = shapes.squircle(n=4)
        color = colors.primary
    elif distance < 6:
        shape = shapes.hexagon()
        color = colors.secondary
    else:
        shape = shapes.triangle()
        color = colors.accent

    # Create polygon
    poly = cell.add_polygon(shape, fill=color)

    # Rotate based on angle from center
    angle = math.degrees(math.atan2(dy, dx))
    poly.rotate(angle)

scene.save("polygon_pattern.svg")

docs.title: Use Shape Helpers
docs.text:
They handle the math for you: 

# Easy
cell.add_polygon(shapes.star(6), fill="gold")

# vs Manual (tedious)
vertices = [(calculate x, calculate y) for each point]

docs.title: Experiment with Squircles
docs.text:
The n parameter creates interesting variations: 

for n in [2, 3, 4, 5, 6]:
    cell.add_polygon(shapes.squircle(n=n), fill="blue")

docs.title: Combine with Rotation
docs.text:
Rotating polygons creates dynamic effects: 

poly = cell.add_polygon(shapes.hexagon())
poly.rotate((cell.row + cell.col) * 15)

docs.title: Text
docs.text: Add typography and labels to your artwork with the Text entity. Full control over fonts, sizes, alignment, and rotation.

docs.title: What is Text?
docs.text:
A Text entity displays typography with: - Content - The text string - Position - Anchor point (x, y) - Font size - Size in pixels - Font family - Typeface - Color - Text color - Alignment - Horizontal and vertical positioning - Rotation - Angle in degrees

Perfect for titles, labels, annotations, and text-based art.

docs.title: Via Cell Method
docs.text:
# Simple text at center
cell.add_text("Hello", font_size=16)

# Custom positioning
cell.add_text(
    content="Label",
    at="top_left",
    font_size=12,
    color="white"
)

# Full control
cell.add_text(
    content="Title",
    at="center",
    font_size=24,
    color="coral",
    font_family="serif",
    text_anchor="middle",
    baseline="middle"
)

docs.title: Direct Construction
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Text

text = Text(
    x=100,
    y=200,
    content="My Label",
    font_size=18,
    color="black",
    font_family="sans-serif"
)

scene.add(text)

docs.title: Properties
docs.text:
text.content        # Text string
text.position       # Anchor point
text.x, text.y      # Coordinates
text.font_size      # Size in pixels
text.color          # Text color
text.font_family    # Typeface
text.text_anchor    # Horizontal alignment
text.baseline       # Vertical alignment
text.rotation       # Degrees
text.z_index        # Layer order

docs.title: Font Families
docs.text:
# Web-safe fonts
cell.add_text("Sans Serif", font_family="sans-serif")  # Default, clean
cell.add_text("Serif", font_family="serif")            # Traditional
cell.add_text("Monospace", font_family="monospace")    # Fixed-width

# Specific fonts (may not be available on all systems)
cell.add_text("Arial", font_family="Arial")
cell.add_text("Georgia", font_family="Georgia")
cell.add_text("Courier", font_family="Courier New")

Recommended: Stick with generic families for maximum compatibility.

docs.title: Text Anchor (Horizontal)
docs.text:
Controls which part of the text sits at the position:

text_anchor="start"   # Left-aligned (position at start)
text_anchor="middle"  # Center-aligned (position at middle) - DEFAULT
text_anchor="end"     # Right-aligned (position at end)

docs.title: Baseline (Vertical)
docs.text:
Controls vertical positioning:

baseline="auto"       # Browser default
baseline="middle"     # Vertically centered - RECOMMENDED
baseline="hanging"    # Top of text at position
baseline="alphabetic" # Baseline at position
baseline="ideographic"  # For CJK text

For centered text: 

cell.add_text(
    "Centered",
    text_anchor="middle",  # Horizontal center
    baseline="middle"      # Vertical center
)

docs.title: Rotation
docs.text:
Rotate text around its anchor point:

# Rotate 45 degrees
cell.add_text("Rotated", rotation=45)

# Vertical text (90 degrees)
cell.add_text("Vertical", rotation=90)

# Upside down
cell.add_text("Flipped", rotation=180)

docs.title: Pattern 1: Grid Labels
docs.text:
scene = Scene.with_grid(cols=8, rows=8, cell_size=30)

# Column headers (A-H)
for col in range(scene.grid.cols):
    cell = scene.grid[0, col]
    label = chr(65 + col)  # A, B, C, ...
    cell.add_text(
        label,
        font_size=14,
        color="white"
    )

# Row numbers (1-8)
for row in range(scene.grid.rows):
    cell = scene.grid[row, 0]
    cell.add_text(
        str(row + 1),
        font_size=14,
        color="white"
    )

docs.text:
scene = Scene.from_image("photo.jpg", grid_size=40)

# Add artwork
for cell in scene.grid:
    cell.add_dot(color=cell.color)

# Title on top
from pyfreeform import Text
title = Text(
    x=scene.width // 2,
    y=30,
    content="My Artwork",
    font_size=32,
    color="white",
    font_family="serif",
    text_anchor="middle",
    z_index=100  # On top
)
scene.add(title)

docs.title: Pattern 3: Data Labels
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    # Show brightness value
    value = f"{cell.brightness:.2f}"

    cell.add_text(
        value,
        font_size=8,
        color="white" if cell.brightness < 0.5 else "black",
        font_family="monospace"
    )

docs.title: Pattern 4: Rotating Text
docs.text:
for cell in scene.grid:
    # Rotation based on position
    angle = (cell.row + cell.col) * 15

    cell.add_text(
        "TEXT",
        font_size=10,
        rotation=angle,
        color=cell.color
    )

docs.title: Font Sizing
docs.text:
Font size is in pixels:

cell.add_text("Small", font_size=10)
cell.add_text("Medium", font_size=16)  # Default
cell.add_text("Large", font_size=24)
cell.add_text("Huge", font_size=36)

Tip: Use relative to cell size: 

size = cell.height * 0.6  # 60% of cell height
cell.add_text("Auto-sized", font_size=size)

docs.title: Layering
docs.text:
Text often needs to be on top:

# Background
cell.add_fill(color="navy", z_index=0)

# Text on top
cell.add_text(
    "LABEL",
    color="white",
    z_index=10
)

docs.title: Complete Example
docs.text:
from pyfreeform import Scene, Palette, Text

docs.title: Example: Custom Paths

Difficulty: 🚀 Advanced

Create custom parametric paths by implementing the Pathable protocol: spirals, waves, and Lissajous curves.

docs.title: What You'll Learn

• Implementing the Pathable protocol
  • Archimedean spiral mathematics (r(θ) = a + bθ)
  • Sinusoidal wave equations
  • Lissajous curve parametric equations
  • Polar to Cartesian coordinate conversion
